page.title: 13WISBOROUGH GREEN GLEBE
page.content: Before the twentieth century the vicar's income depended on tithes from the local farmers. Each farmer donated one tenth of his income. He was then entitled to his own seat in the church. These pews can be seen in the church with the names of the farms carved on them. The vicar also had his Glebe. The Wisborough Green Glebe includes the Glebe field, between the pond and the church, and the land on which the vicarage and Glebe Way now stand. On this land the vicar could pasture his animals. This land was taken over by the state, and the income given to the church, in 1920. The vicar was the only person in the village who was allowed to brew and sell beer. The brewhouse is still there.
